bestBHT.bht: The widow in this account continually comes before the judge, seeking justice and asking him to avenge her from the oppression she faces. It is noted that judges were obligated to pay special attention to widows, as they were defenseless and often subject to oppression. The widow's unwavering persistence implies the justice of her cause, even as she represents the church, who should solely seek God for vengeance against her adversaries. Seeking justice should be done, not for personal reasons, but to bring glory to God.

Henry Alford: Avenge me of... or perhaps, deliver me from—the justice of her cause being presupposed...
Albert Barnes: Judges were bound to show special attention to widows, Isaiah 1:17; Jeremiah 22:3. The reason of this was that they were defenseless, were commonly poor, and were liable to be oppressed by those in power.

Avenge me - This would have been better translated, 'Do me justice against my adversary, or vindicate me from him.' It does not denote vengeance or revenge, but simply that she wished to have 'justice' done her - a thing which this judge was 'bound' to do, but which it seems he had no disposition to do.
Adversary - One opposed in law. In this case it seems that the judge was unwilling to do justice, and probably took advantage of her condition to oppress her.
Marvin Vincent: Avenge [εκδικησον] . The word is too strong. It means do me justice. See on Romans 12:19.
Philip Schaff: The suitor may represent the church.
The justice of her cause is implied throughout.
The Church of Christ, persecuted for ages, should proffer this request to God alone.
Archibald T. Robertson: Came oft (ηρχετο). Imperfect tense denotes repetitions, no adverb for 'oft' in the Greek.
Avenge me of (εκδικησον με απο). A late verb for doing justice, protecting one from another.
Deissmann (Light from the Ancient East, pp. 420ff.) quotes a στηλη of the second century B.C. with a prayer for vengeance for a Jewish girl that had been murdered which has this very verb εκδικεω.
John Gill: Christ is the bridegroom of his church and people; he is their husband, the Lord of hosts is his name; and they are espoused as a chaste virgin to him.
Many are the adversaries of God's people, as the sins and corruptions of their own hearts, Satan, and his angels, wicked oppressors, and persecutors.
It does not become the people of God to avenge themselves, even when it is in the power of their hands; nor should they desire it for their own sakes, so much as for the glory of God.

bhtAttempts.bht: The widow in this verse is seeking justice, asking the judge to avenge her from the oppression she faces. The judge, however, seems to have no inclination to do what is right. The reason for showing special attention to widows is that they are defenseless and often oppressed by those in power. The justice of her cause is implicit in her continual coming before the judge. This widow, representing the church, asks God alone for vengeance against her adversaries. It is important for the people of God to seek justice, not for their own sake, but for the glory of God.
